Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2010 01:06AM - edited Feb 26, 2010 01:08AM by Beatis gscott, You have posted this question on several places on this website. I have seen it on a lot of other sites as well. As has been pointed out here by LindaLou53 and others, the numbers do NOT refer to survival rates, but to the contribution of chemotherapy to overall cure, compared to other therapies the patients have undergone. You can compare it with wanting to know what makes the biggest contribution to weight loss: exercise, diet, weight loss pills, etc. You consistently seem to want to misunderstand this. I wonder why that is. Btw, the study you are referring to also has some major flaws, which you can read about here.
Posts.Title: How many here have survived 6 years after chemo? gscott Beatis

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2010 07:59AM - edited Jun 6, 2010 08:02AM by Beatis It's not the same as the BRCA test.  It think it may be this: http://medgadget.com/archives/2007/02/mammaprint_a_br.html This test has been used in the Netherlands since it came on the market (it was developed in collaboration with Dutch scientists) and was paid for by the hospitals themselves. Dutch health insurers have now decided to standardly pay for testing with MamaPrint. I believe some health insurers in the USA also pay for this test. It will significantly reduce the number of women having to undergo chemotherapy.
